acquaintance: a person that you have met but do not know well
addition: the process of adding numbersor amounts together
aisle: a long, narrow space between rows ofseats in an aircraft, cinema, or church
amendment: a change or changes made to the words of a text
appear: to start to be seen or to be present
appearance: an occasion when someone appears in public
to apply: to request something, usuallyofficially, especially in writing or by sending in a form
to appreciate: to recognize how good someone or something is and to value him, her, or it
baggy: hanging loosely because of being too big or having been stretched
be reluctant: not willing to do something and therefore slow to do it
to betray: to not be loyal to your country or a person, often by doing something harmful such as helping their enemies
betrayal: an act of betraying someone or something, or the fact of someone or something being betrayed
borrow: to get or receive something from someone with the intention of giving it back after a period of time
breadwinner: the member of a family who earns themoney that the family needs
coincide: to happen at or near the same time,  to be the same or similar
compare: to examine or look for the difference between two or more things
cope with: to deal successfully with a difficult situation
correction: a change made to something in order to correct or improve it, or theaction of making such a change
customer: a person who buys goods or aservice
disadvatages: a condition or situation that causesproblems, especially one that causes something or someone to be less successful than other things or people
doubt: (a feeling of) not being certain about something, especially about how good or true it is
drawbacks: a disadvantage or the negative partof a situation
enrich: to improve the quality of something by adding something else
to exploit: to use something in a way that helps you
failure: the fact of someone or something not succeeding
